text:
I was in a meeting, today, where someone was talking about ecommerce. The speaker highly recommends Shopify, saying WordPress is hacked a lot because it's open-source.

This struck me as odd.

It doesn't seem to me as if the open-source nature of something is what opens it to hacking, but the fact that something is in widespread use, like Windows or WordPress.

Anyone else have any insight?

One of my partner's businesses is an ecommerce business for which I built him a WordPress site using WooCommerce. I have made zero modifications to WooCommerce or to the payment gateway plugin, because I didn't want to risk anything, and I've got Really Simple SSL as a plugin to help handle security. The nature of the business is that Shopify would disallow it, which is why we (I) chose WordPress a few years ago when we were first starting the business. (My partner is clueless about any of this, so it was up to me.)

I know that it's extremely important to keep WordPress and its themes and plugins updated religiously, which I do.

But now I'm paranoid. (Or more paranoid than I was, which was pretty paranoid.)

Does anyone have any words of wisdom?

There's NO WAY I would try to build an ecommerce site from scratch myself, using what we've learned so far in this boot camp, but I'm fairly confident that I'm capable of managing WordPress with WooCommerce and Authorize with no modifications. I would never do this for anyone other than myself or my partner, though.

Am I kidding myself?

I would never do this for anyone other than myself or my partner, though.

Am I kidding myself?

text: My partner runs his own business that helps people w/their sites. His advice is to make sure you're on Nexcess.  They have dedicated WooCommerce Hosting.  It checks integrity & security nightly.  And also get WorkFence premium a firewall plugin.  Do not use any plugin that's not premium or paid & supported. You can  also use CodeCanon elite authors.

text: you can open the console. There is an option to view mobile. You can then select various layouts to see how things look.  You can also create a custom viewport if you know the approximate pixel sizes.  It's not a perfect solution, but it's a start. And it's free so it has that going for it. There are several professional tools out there that will do a top notch job at mimicking layouts based on viewport sizes, but you don't need to pay for those right now. Let the employer foot that bill!!!! :wink:

text:
I have multiple e commerce sites running just fine on WP.  There are a couple added steps to ensure security, but there's lots of plugins to help in that area as well. That's one of the huge benefits of the WP platform!

Shopify is also an excellent alternative. But it comes at an added cost and complexity that many DIYers just can't handle. A statistically significant portion of the e-commerce sites out there are built on WP for that very reason.

text:
You already hit on one of the key considerations to WP security.
Keep everything up to date...
Enable auto updates if you have not already done so. (I bet you have!:wink:)
Use only verified and trusted plugins from reputable authors.

I do have some experimental WP installations where I'm mucking about with CSS and PHP, but they're not e-commerce installations.
